dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRIS GARDNER, sits on a park bench with his girlfriend L near a busy amusement park pier in Venice. Linda is a few months pregnant. Chris wears a navy Seaman’s uniform. Oth sailors wait near a small bus across the street; one is waving Chris over. The script Venice, California 1976 appears.

dialogues.speaker: SAILOR
dialogues.text: (calling Chris to the bus) We have to get back to the ship! Chris ignores the guy. Something heavy’s going on between Linda and Chris. They both seem blue.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (to Linda, calmly) I’m almost out. One more year. Then I’1l get a good job. And I’1l take care of him. Hey. Chris has said “hey” to get Linda to face him because she hasn’t been. She does. CHRIS (CONT’D) I never had a dad. That’s not going to happen to him. I’1l always take care of him.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: You didn’t want to be in this kind of thing.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What kind of thing?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Kid. Not married. No jobs. No real jobs. Neither did I She’s sad over the event of her pregnancy. Chris tries to cheer her in his calm way.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I’1l get some good work after the navy. It’s going to be fine. It’s going to be. Chris makes a brave face for Linda, but something about h demeanor shows he knows, because of the pregnancy, that h in a hard spot now he never wished to be in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the more urban setting of San Francisco, trash in City San Francisco cans is laid out for pick up in the beaten tenderloin district.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A row of low income housing and two-story motels make up city block in this same neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris waits to cross a street in San Francisco. He’s with son CHRISTOPHER, 5. Chris wears a coat and tie and carrie pretty large, square machine of some kind. The script San Francisco, 1981 appears.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Maybe I should make a list

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: For your birthday gifts?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Well, you know, you’re just going to get a couple things.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Just to look at. And study. So I can choose better.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Can you spell everything you’re thinking of? Christopher thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Okay. Make a list. That’s smart. The light changes. They start to cross. CHRIS (CONT’D) Are you doing okay in here? Chris has nodded up ahead to a city-neighborhood, cut-ra daycare.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Yeah... Can we go to the park today? After?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I’m taking the bus back from Oakland. I don’t know when I’1l1 get home. EXT. MRS. CHU’S DAYCARE, SAN FRANCISCO - LATER Chris leaves the daycare building after leaving Christoph there. But he turns and looks back at the building. He’s looking at their poorly-maintained mural of kids playing. The paint’s peeling. There’s graffiti over kid’s faces. And someone’s written Fuck in spray paint on it. Then Chris looks at the daycare motto painted above. mrs. Chu’s Daycare. Fun, Joy, Happyness. Chris looks at the wo Happyness. Time passes. Then he speaks to a Chinese dayca maintenance worker who’s sweeping out there.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: That’s misspelled.

dialogues.speaker: MAINTENANCE WORKER
dialogues.text: Hui hyu tsa.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Happiness? There’s no y. After p. The guy keeps sweeping. Chris keeps looking at the wall, he looks inside the window at his son. Inside there, Christopher’s playing with blocks by himself - he looks m lonesome than pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Christopher plays quietly, Chris stands outside the window looking in. Christopher doesn’t see him.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I’m Chris Gardner. EXT. MRS. CHU’S - SAME Chris remains at the window on the San Francisco sidewalk looking in at his son. He’s watching Christopher play with the blocks alone ins There, a dog no one’s paying attention to walks right acr the kid’s play area over to a food bowl; there’s spilled laying around his bowl. It’s a cramped, unhappy setting f kids. Then Chris looks away from the window.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This is part of my life story. He looks at his watch. Late for something, Chris starts running off with his machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris sits on a bus bench in the city; the guy beside him drunk Filipino with a screw loose, 60, in a T-shirt that reads World’s Greatest Dad. Chris keeps the machine on hi lap. The two sit there waiting for the bus.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This part, in the eighties... this part’s called Riding the Bus. All of a sudden, the Filipino guy faces Chris and looks astonished.

dialogues.speaker: FILIPINO GUY
dialogues.text: Holy shit, did you just crystallize from nowhere? The guy points at Chris’s machine. FILIPINO GUY (CONT’D) That’s a time machine. Holy shit. The bus arrives. FILIPINO GUY (CONT’D) (laughing) Holy shit, man. Chris’s expression shows the guy’s disturbing his peace. stands up to catch the bus.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Chris rides through east San Francisco; he’s staring out window like he’s got something heavy on his mind. He keep the machine on his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That’s a bone density scanner.

dialogues.speaker: FILIPINO GUY
dialogues.text: This guy has a time machine! This one fucker! The Filipino’s seated in the row behind Chris, looking through the crack between the seats; he’s addressing ever on the bus. FILLIPINO GUY (CONT’D) He crystallized beside me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris waits for a transfer bus on a bench alone; he’s sta at the machine on his lap.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Where would I go if it was one? If it was a time machine I wondered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris carries his scanner as he walks through the city.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Two years back, probably, before I took this job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DOCTOR and Chris part company before the entranceway to Francis Hospital. Chris still has his scanner.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This thing was unnecessary and expensive. It gave a slightly denser picture than an x-ray, for a ton more money.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: We just don’t need it, Chris. It’s unnecessary. And expensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A still image of Chris standing among a crowd of San Franciscans waiting for a walk light; he’s staring at the scanner like he has personal hard feelings toward it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was the business I bought into, when we moved to San Francisco. *what follows is a montage of still images of Chris with scanner in assorted places around San Francisco, waiting corners, waiting for the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris walks up a sidewalk. A guy leaves a parked Mercedes short distance ahead of him. Chris has been watching him.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (making eye contact) Hey...

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES OWNER
dialogues.text: Hi... Chris looks at the car. Then he looks at the guy again.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: How are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES OWNER
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (smiling) Did you have to go to college to do your job?

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES OWNER
dialogues.text: (smiling back) Yeah. I’m a structural engineer Yeah. Chris nods. The light changes. Chris starts to cross the street. Then he checks his watch and starts to run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris runs along the sidewalk beyond a busy Oakland stree he’s carrying his scanner.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: That’s my car. In the foreground, among the cars parked on the streetsid is a hazel Riviera with a yellow Denver boot locked down the front wheel. A policeman writes a ticket beside the c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris jogs with the scanner up the walkway to the main entrance of Oakland Memorial Hospital.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There’s limited parking near hospitals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris rides up the elevator, holding his scanner box.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I made four hundred and eighteen dollars on each sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris carries his scanner down a long hallway.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: A thirty dollar ticket every three days was a business expense. I thought I’d take it out of the commission on my scanners. As I sold them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris walks out the same doors he entered on his way in; STILL HAS THE SCANNER, THOUGH.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I just wasn’t selling any. INT. CHRIS’S HAZEL RIVIERA - LATER This is a shot through the windshield of Chris’s parked c Bright orange tickets cover the lower half of the windshi Chris is visible through the clear space of the glass walking across the street up ahead, carrying his scanner.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And I needed at least one commission a week to cover rent and daycare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, Chris sits on a bus bench beside an unaccompanied Chinese kid trying to play a trumpet; it’s nearly evening

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (facing the kid) Would you stop that? The kid stops and faces Chris.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: (to Chris) Hu xia tu hi ma. The kids sits quietly for a moment, then he resumes playi the trumpet.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So... the bus... The bus pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Chris rides beside the window, with his bone scanner, loo out at the landscape.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: All I’m saying... riding the bus somedays is a drag. The kid’s playing the trumpet somewhere behind him. Chris sits there for a while. He’s sharing the row with a real heavy guy and he’s sort of over against the wall with his machine.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I remember... I think it was this day... I remember I actually tried it. Chris looks down at his scanner.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Just in case that crazy fucker was somehow right. Chris keeps staring at the machine.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I had this stupid thought, or wish that maybe he was right and everyone else was crazy, and maybe I was a time traveler and didn’t know it and could really go somewhere else if I pushed the button. CLOSE ON CHRIS as he considers this. He puts his finger the black button.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And I actually pushed the button... like an idiot... Chris pushes the button on his medical machine.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...and went nowhere. Chris sits there for a moment. He’s gone nowhere of cours Soon, he turns and looks out the window. The city’s going beyond him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris walks down the sidewalk with the scanner. He comes a young man paying a meter for a parked Ferrari; Chris ha looked at the guy and the car.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (to the guy, saying hi) Hey.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI OWNER
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something?

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI OWNER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (to the guy) What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI OWNER
dialogues.text: (looking over) What? For a job?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI OWNER
dialogues.text: I’m a stockbroker. Time passes.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Do you have to go to college?  10.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI OWNER
dialogues.text: Have to?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. More time goes by.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI OWNER
dialogues.text: You don’t have to. Chris nods. The guy’s said it to mean you don’t have to b you sure should. Then Chris starts to cross the street. INT. CHRIS’S APARTMENT - LATER (NIGHT) Chris and Linda eat dinner at the kitchen table without speaking. Linda wears a grocery worker’s uniform. The apartment’s small and unadorned with anything. Some time passes during which there’s the heavy silence between a couple not getting along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda cleans up after dinner. Chris walks past and sees a RUBIK’S CUBE resting on a kitchen counter

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: A gift for Christopher.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: From who?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Cynthia. From work. It’s for adults. It’s an adult thing. Chris can’t use it. She didn’t know.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: You’re supposed to make every side a solid color. Chris picks the thing up. LINDA (CONT’D) Did you pay the taxes?  11.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I filed an extension...

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: You already filed an extension.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I had to file another one. The bill was six hundred and fifty. I’1l have it in September.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: That means interest. Right?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Some. Money seems to be a source of conflict for them. Rather t deal with it further, Linda leaves the room. Chris remain there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris has come out on the patio idly with the cube; it’s a patio in the sense that one would derive enjoyment from sitting there. It’s cement space outside the kitchen. Eac small apartment in the complex has one, so Chris is sitti five feet from his neighbor’s patios on either side. He’s started messing with the cube. Time passes like this whil Chris, over a minute or so in real time, SOLVES THREE SID OF THE RUBIK’S CUBE COMPLETELY. His thoughts are somewher else, though, so he doesn’t care to finish. He just puts thing down and goes back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris and Linda share the real small space of their bathr Chris brushes his teeth. Linda’s finishing dressing for w they’re in the middle of an argument.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (upset about it) Does he have to be in daycare from 6:30 in the morning?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (pissed too) Can you watch him?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I need to be in the financial district. Before work.  12.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I have to open. It’s the nineteenth. We have to pay rent next week. I need both shifts. Linda tries to leave and bumps Chris’s shoulder. LINDA (CONT’D) Fuck... Linda walks out. Chris is left alone. He stands there for while. Then he resumes brushing his teeth. A few moments by. Chris rises up and looks in the mirror for a while; h sizing himself up. Time passes while Chris looks at himse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris has followed Linda into their bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I just want to go by Dean Witter. Before work.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I want to see about a job.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: What job?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I want some information about a job there.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: What job?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Stockbroker. Linda looks at Chris like he’s aiming off the mark for wh likely or best for them. CHRIS (CONT’D) I could go through a math book ina week when I was a kid. I want to see about it.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I have to open. So you have Christopher.  13.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I’1l go by during the day.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: You should probably do your sales calls. Sell what’s in your contract and get us out of that business, Chris. Fuck, Chris. Okay? Linda has finished dressing and leaves the room. Chris watches her go. INT. CHRISTOPHER’S BEDROOM - LATER Christopher’s sleeping. The clock beside his bed reads 5: Chris sits on the bed, waking him up.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Christopher...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris and his son have breakfast. The table’s in the kitc The kitchen’s real small. It’s pretty early. Christopher’ holding a cereal spoon. But his eyes are closed and he’s motionless. Chris looks over at him.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (trying to wake him up) Pssst. Christopher’s eyes open. Chris looks at him. There’s a sm black and white TV on the counter that plays local news; there, a field reporter’s holding a Rubik’s Cube up for t camera.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: ...is shaping up to the be the gift sensation of 1981. Don’t expect to solve it easily, although we encountered a math professor at USF who took just thirty minutes on his. Chris notices the TV. He’s getting the idea the cube’s a challenge he could pass easily. He looks back at Christop Christopher’s eyes are closed again. Chris looks at him w bad feelings he’s got his son up so early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris is freshly dressed for work and is holding a scanne he sits waiting for the San Francisco city bus.  14. The kid with the trumpet sits beside him, playing it. Chr stares straight ahead like he’s determined about somethin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Businessmen and women walk around the financial district. Soon, Chris becomes visible, turning a corner onto the sa sidewalk, joining the group of traders and brokers. He st and looks across the street at a Dean Witter branch offic he’s holding the scanner. Then he turns back the way he c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down the street, Chris speaks with a GIRL JUNKIE who sits couple steps up apartment stairs off the sidewalk. The scanner rests at Chris’s feet; Chris holds some dollar bi

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Can I give you a couple dollars? You can watch this for me? I’m going in for a meeting. I don’t want to bring this in and look small time.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL JUNKIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Chris hands the girl the money. Something occurs to him.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (doesn’t want her to steal it) It can’t be sold anywhere. It’s medical equipment. It can’t be sold anywhere. I can’t even sell them, and it’s my job. I’1l give you some more money when I get back.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL JUNKIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris sits alone in the reception area. Then TIM BROPHY enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: TIM BROPHY
dialogues.text: Chris?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (standing quickly) Hi.  15.

dialogues.speaker: TIM BROPHY
dialogues.text: (offering his hand) Tim Brophy. Resources. I was going out to grab a coffee. Do you want to come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris and Tim Brophy have come outside to a nearby public park square. They’re mid-conversation, sitting together o the low, perimeter wall of the park fountain.

dialogues.speaker: TIM BROPHY
dialogues.text: Here’s an ap. For our internship. That’s all we can do for you here. Brophy hands the application to Chris.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Thanks... TIM BROPHY (CONT’D) We have a resume sheet, too. We’ve had a lot of applications, though. We're out.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS HAS NOTICED SOMETHING ACROSS THE PARK, THOUGH
dialogues.text: JUNKIE’S CARRYING HIS SCANNER OFF. She’s walked away with into the city. TIM BROPHY (CONT’D) You can pick one up at your school. We send them out.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Mr. Brophy, I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: TIM BROPHY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I have to. Thanks. Then Chris rises and runs off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris sprints through a large group of young market trade on break.  16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl junkie with the scanner takes the stairs up to t train. It’s a long shot that shows city sidewalk a good distance behind her; Chris is visible down there running toward her. But the train comes and blocks the view. The train sits there, obscuring anything that’s happening beh it. After a while, it moves along, and when it’s totally of frame it reveals Chris standing on the station platfor all alone without his scanner, having reached it too late

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I rode up and down looking for her. That day.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Chris stands near the window of the moving train, watchin the city landscape pass outside.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: This train’s moving the other way. Chris is seated now. H looks at the papers Brophy gave him.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There were three blank lines after “High School” to list more education. The program took just twenty people every six months. One got a job. The internship paid nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris leaves a train later with some others. He walks acr the platform toward the stairs, then he puts the applicat in the trash can by the steps and keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s just sunrise so there’s little traffic. Chris and Christopher leave Linda at a bus stop bench for her ride work and start walking off on their own somewhere; Chris carries a scanner, Christopher a backpack.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (to Chris, about the scanner, kidding sort of) Come back without that, please.  17.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (trying to be light- hearted about it) I’m going to. Say goodbye to it. Because I’m coming back without it.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (to the scanner, just slightly amused) Goodbye. And good riddance.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (trying to kid) You didn’t have to add “good riddance.”

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (to Chris and Christopher) Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris and Christopher have walked farther into east San Francisco, past a park where one guy’s shooting baskets. Christopher’s watching him.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: That’s not how you spell it.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: P-p-y. It’s an “i.” Happiness.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: That’s an adjective?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s just not spelled right

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Is “fuck” right? Chris doesn’t say anything for a while.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. But that’s not part of the motto. So... you’re not supposed to learn that. It’s a grown up word. To show anger, and other things. Drop it, okay?  18.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What’s it say on your bag? That tape?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: My nickname. We picked nicknames.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What’s it say?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Hot Rod. Did you have a nickname? Chris thinks for a while.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Ten Gallon Head...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I lived in Louisiana, near Texas. Before I joined the navy. People wore cowboy hats. A ten gallon’s a big hat. I was good at school. I was smart when I was a kid, so they called me Ten Gallon Head.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Hoss wears that hat.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Hoss?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Hoss Cartwright. On Bonanza.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: How do you know Bonanza?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: I watch Bonanza at Mrs. Chu’s.  19.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You watch Bonanza at daycare? Christopher’s gotten distracted by a Chinese pushcart passing. CHRIS (CONT’D) Hey. You watch Bonanza at daycare? Christopher nods. CHRIS (CONT’D) When?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: When do you watch it? After snack? After your nap?...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: After Love Boat. Chris looks down at his son, getting pissed.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (quietly) Fuck...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: I made my list. For my birthday.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (distracted, thinking about the TV issue) What did you pick?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I’m running somewhere. And I can’t talk to you about numbers and shit right now. The light changes. Chris takes off.

dialogues.speaker: ACQUAINTANCE
dialogues.text: (to himself) What’s your problem with numbers?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (stopping in the street) Wayne.

dialogues.speaker: ACQUAINTANCE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You owe me fourteen bucks.

dialogues.speaker: ACQUAINTANCE
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Do you have that?

dialogues.speaker: ACQUAINTANCE
dialogues.text: I’1l get that to you. Chris takes off again. ACQUAINTANCE (CONT’D) (to himself again) Fourteen’s a number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris HOLDS A SINGLE PEN and waits for his turn to pay.  41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris sits on a bench outside the grocery with his new pe he’s writing the address down on the paper he has. He finishes. He looks at it. FOR THE FIRST TIME, CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: DEMONSTRATES A SENSE OF SLIGHT RELIEF AND SATISFACTION. H
dialogues.text: remains on the bench, resting for a while. Then he notice the paper is the list Christopher’s made earlier. Chris l at it. The paper bears handwriting that reads basketball... microscope... two records... Chris looks at the paper for a while; he’s thinking about son. EXT. MS. CHU’S DAYCARE, SAN FRANCISCO - DAY Chris is amped up and has caught up with Linda in front o daycare. Christopher’s gone in; left alone, they take the occasion to scream at one another.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You didn’t leave me a pen.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Chris--

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Did you know he watches nonsense in here? He watches TV in here?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You set this up. I wouldn’t have set this up. I would have looked in this fucking place. Take off. But I want Christopher. Give me Christopher if you want to take off. A DAYCARE WORKER has come out to quiet them.

dialogues.speaker: DAYCARE WORKER
dialogues.text: There’s children in here. She goes back in. The couple look at one another. Then th finish with each other by whispering fiercely.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You set this up.  42.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: We didn’t have a choice. It’s all we could pay for.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Where are you staying?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: At Cynthia’s.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: There’s no room for Christopher there. I’m taking him if you’re staying there. Why are you staying there?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Until I can figure out where I’m going. All right? Until I figure out what I want to do. I want to do something different. Just-- That’s where I’m staying. Linda walks off. Chris watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris sits on a bus bench across the street from the dayc building. He’s looking across the street, into the center where the class is being collected to leave for the day. Chris stands up to go retrieve Christopher. EXT. MS. CHU’S DAYCARE - CONTINUOUS Christopher’s come out front with some others. Chris is there, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Hi...

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Yeah. Where’s mom? Chris doesn’t answer right away. They start walking off.  43.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: She went to stay with a friend for a little while.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Cynthia?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: She wants to be alone for a while to do some thinking.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Thinking about what?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Just... About how to be happy. All right? I’m with you. You’re going to be fine. Christopher looks a little mixed up. They’ve come to a co and stopped. Chris looks down at his son. CHRIS (CONT’D) She just wants to do some thinking. You’re going to be fine. He smiles as a means to reassure Christopher. Christopher nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris has met his apartment landlord in front of the offi Chris holds his lease; they’re discussing it.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: The apartment’s in good shape. You have to keep this fifty dollar cleanup?

dialogues.speaker: LANDLORD
dialogues.text: That’s a touchup fee. Repainting.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I’1l paint it.  44.

dialogues.speaker: LANDLORD
dialogues.text: That’s all right. Why are you moving? Chris looks at the guy for a while.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Linda’s moved out. We need a smaller space. INT. CHRIS’S APARTMENT - LATER Chris paints the walls white; he’s dressed in old clothes doesn’t care about. It’s an unhappy scene with the scanne stack visible in the frame. He’s got to edge past a scann to paint.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (to the scanner for some reason) Watch out. He knocks the scanner aside with his foot. It didn’t go a far as he needed. CHRIS (CONT’D) (starting to lose it) Watch out, asshole. He knocks it harder, then he looks at the scanner with th loose bearings of a guy who just called some equipment “asshole.” CHRIS (CONT’D) Fuckin’... Shit. Asshole. Then he kicks the equipment. Then he pushes his ladder do on the scanner. CHRIS (CONT’D) Fucker. Then Chris really kicks its midsection hard. He’s a littl winded and stops. He looks at the damage he’s caused. CHRIS (CONT’D) (realizing he busted it) Shit... After a while, he sits down beside the scanner. Chris tak piece that flew off and tries to put it back on.  45. CHRIS (CONT’D) (more calmly) Fit. Come on. It’s not going back on. CHRIS (CONT’D) (quietly) Come on. I’m sorry. Chris keeps trying to fix the equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris sits on the small cement patio. He’s got his face pressed against the green mesh chain link of the rail. CLOSE ON Chris’s face meshed in; it’s an uncomfortable- looking position but one he’s apparently taking some comf from temporarily.

dialogues.speaker: APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Chris paints with a roller when THERE’S A KNOCK AT THE DO He goes to answer it and walks past part of the wall wher he’s painted in broad white paint Chris, You suck, Chris

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: Chris opens the door. TWO SAN FRANCISCO POLICEMAN stand outside.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Chris Gardner? Chris looks back at the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three inmates sit around a station jail cell - Chris and others. Chris remains in his painting clothes.

dialogues.speaker: INMATE
dialogues.text: (to Chris) What‘’d you do? Chris doesn’t answer.  46.

dialogues.speaker: INMATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Chris) What‘’d you do? The other guy starts laughing.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND INMATE
dialogues.text: (laughing) Parking tickets. After a moment, the first guy begins to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: INMATE
dialogues.text: (laughing, to Chris) You got to pay that shit. INT. CASHIER’S OFFICE, POLICE STATION - LATER Chris writes a check for the clerk.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Four hundred?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Four eighty. It’s a heavy amount for Chris. CLERK (CONT’D) That’s a county tax. (taking the check) You have to stay until this clears. We verify at nine-thirty A.M.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (worried for Christopher) My son’s at school. I have to get him.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: It’s nine-thirty A.M.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I have a job interview at 10:15. At Dean Witter. And my son’s at--

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: We verify at nine-thirty. Though he’s concerned, Chris has to accept this.  47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris is on the pay phone down the end of the long jail corridor; though he’s talking calmly, his expression show he’s feeling great unrest.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (meaning what do you want) What?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I have to... I can’t get Christopher today.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I need you to get Christopher. Take him with you. For the night. One night.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (quietly) I got stuck. In this... situation. I’1l get him at school tomorrow. I’1l go right there.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Maybe I should take him.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You should take him for the night Like I’m asking. To help us.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I want to see him... Chris doesn’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I want to see him.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: See him tomorrow. Then bring him back. There’s no response.  48. CHRIS (CONT’D) See him then bring him home.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I want to take him to Golden Gate. To the park. I’11 bring him back at six. Chris doesn’t say yes or no.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Six. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Linda... Chris weighs what Linda has in mind.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (meaning it better be six and no later) Six. Chris is leaned way in with his head pressed into the cor of the phone box; there’s pain on his face like someone’s hitting his head with a hammer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the middle of the night, while the few other inmates sleep, Chris lays in his space awake.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I was wondering how I was going to get over to Dean Witter in time. Without a dime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one’s out on the front steps of the station the next morning. The setting looks like a still picture. Then the doors fly open, and Chris comes running out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris tears down the sidewalk, running past business peop

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris sprints down the sidewalk toward the Dean Witter building. He’s wearing a gray Member’s Only jacket, no sh under and white jeans covered in old paint.  49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris stands in front of the skyscraper lobby entrance fighting with the busted front zipper of his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (struggling with the zipper ) Fuck... Then Chris gives up on it. He stands there for a moment having to accept the fact that he has to conduct an inter this way.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Surrounded by business people, Chris rides the elevator u his painter pants and his open Members Only.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Dean Witter applicants in suits wait together in a of reception room seats. Chris sits directly in the middl them. A RECEPTIONIST enters from the inter-office to call Chris for his interview.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Mr. Gardner? Chris rises.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Thank you. Chris walks past her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of DEAN WITTER PARTNERS waits for Chris in the bo room. Chris and the receptionist enter.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: (introducing him) Chris Gardner. The men look at Chris. Jay Twistle is part of the group. Chris looks back at them.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Hi. More or less embarrassed, the group has gone quiet.  50. CHRIS (CONT’D) ... I’ve been sitting out there for a half hour thinking of a story about some series of events that would have led me to be here like this. Dressed like this. And also would have demonstrated qualities you probably value here like diligence and earnestness and maybe team-playing or something... The partners look at Chris. CHRIS (CONT’D) I couldn’t think of anything. I was arrested for failure to pay parking tickets. I ran here from the Polk station. From the police station. The partners keep looking at Chris.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: I have a question. Chris looks back. The guy checks out his clothes. FIRST PARTNER (CONT’D) What were you doing before you were arrested? The others laugh. Chris has smiled. There’s some good che in the room now.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I was painting my apartment.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: Sit down. Chris begins to sit. FIRST PARTNER (CONT’D) (gesturing for Chris to stop) Is it dry?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yes... Chris sits down.  51.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: (to Chris) Jay says you’re pretty determined.

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE
dialogues.text: He’s been waiting out front with some forty pound gizmo for a month.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: He said you’re smart. Chris looks over at Twistle. The look is meant to thank J Jay returns Chris’s look to say he’s in Chris’s corner. FIRST PARTNER (CONT’D) Do you think you can learn regulations and operations of the market so as to capitalize?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: Have you already starting learning? On your own?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: Because that’s all we do. The partner looks Chris over. FIRST PARTNER (CONT’D) We generally hire M.B.A.s from good schools. We like to be prepared in case a client asks where an employee went to school. Chris listens like that’s bad news. FIRST PARTNER (CONT’D) But it’s been my experience that they don’t. They ask whether they’re profiting through our service. (turning to Jay) Jay, how many times have you seen Chris?

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE
dialogues.text: Ten.  52.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: Has he ever been dressed like this? Chris awaits the answer.

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE
dialogues.text: No. Jacket and tie.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: (looking at his resume) You were first in your class? In high school?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: Out of how many?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Twelve. No one reacts like it’s much of an accomplishment. CHRIS (CONT’D) Small town.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: I’l1l say.

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE
dialogues.text: First is first, though.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: Yes, first is first, Jay.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I was first in radar class in the navy also. Twenty guys.

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE
dialogues.text: If Chris finishes first here, he’s made us a lot of money. The first partner looks at Chris for a while.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: What would you say if I told you a guy showed up for a interview without a shirt. And I hired him. What would you say to that? Chris thinks about it.  The whole character

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: He must have had a pretty nice pair of pants. room laughs. Chris has accomplished sharing some strengths with this group.

dialogues.speaker: WITTER BUILDING, SKYSCRAPER LOBBY
dialogues.text: Twistle has walked Chris out; they finish a conversation front of the skyscraper.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Twistle.

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE
dialogues.text: You can call me Jay.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (nodding) I’1l let you know, Jay.

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE
dialogues.text: (totally surprised by that) What?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (not following) What?

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE
dialogues.text: You’1l let me know, Jay?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE
dialogues.text: You hounded-- You stood here--

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: There’s no salary. My circumstances changed some. I need to figure out if I can make it.

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE
dialogues.text: A couple hours. No shit. I’1l fill your spot. I promise. You know what I’1l look like... if you back out, you know what I’11 look like to the partners?  54.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: An ass-- (thinking better of it) --a-hole.

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE
dialogues.text: Yes. An ass a-hole. All the way. Amused, Twistle has smiled. Chris has smiled too from the simple enjoyment of his company; all in all it’s a moment relief for Chris amid all his long stretches of unhappine

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris runs back home from the building.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There was no salary. And not even a reasonable promise of a job. One intern was hired at the end of the program. From a pool of twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris keeps running.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: If you weren’t that guy, you couldn’t apply the six months training to another broker. I'd have to quit formally working for Acro as well. I'd have to give up benefits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris removes his watch, slowing from his run and approac the pawn shop.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The only resource I would have for six months would be my scanners, which I owned on lease and could still sell. I had fifteen left. If I sold them all, I might get by.  55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris waits among other at the central San Francisco trai platform.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I had two hours to decide.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Chris rides by the window. He’s looking out at the landsc of the city. It’s fall. The afternoon light’s fading out. Chris has gone quiet like he was at the film’s beginning, riding the train and considering the matters of his life.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I remember wondering... Am I a good bet? Or not. Because all this was was a bet I could shine. INT. CHRIS’S APARTMENT - LATER Chris is alone in the apartment, standing under his broad Suck message. With a brush, he begins to cover it with pa Once it’s painted over, Chris shows a degree of relief. T he checks his kitchen clock. The clock reads five minutes to six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hris sits alone outside on the stairwell steps waiting fo hristopher. Qo INT. CHRIS’S APARTMENT - LATER t’s almost dark. Chris looks out the window of his room t he stairwell where Linda should come up. She’s not there. hris checks his watch. He’s worried. Soon, Linda comes up he stairs. She’s carrying Christopher because he’s asleep hris lets some apprehension go. OctOctH

dialogues.speaker: NT. LIVING ROOM, MOTEL ROOM
dialogues.text: Linda has put Christopher down on the couch under the mes Chris painted over; he’s still asleep. They face one anot from five feet away.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (meaning where’s he been) What were you doing?  56.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I had to, I had to manage all this stuff. I had an interview at Dean Witter. I had to get there. For an intern program. A competitive program. I got it. Linda has been listening.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I’m going back to Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: All right... They keep facing one another. CHRIS (CONT’D) I want Christopher. Here. Linda looks at Chris for a while; sizing him up.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Salesman to intern’s backwards. You’re fucking around.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (with some anger, trying to stay quiet.) I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: What are you going to do for money?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I’m going to sell those things I leased. And I’m going to stand out. In my program.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: You’re doing that? Chris doesn’t answer her. Linda stands there for a while. vibe of Linda is she’s lost, disappointed with her lot an uncertain over the important concerns of her life; she’s considering all of what Chris said to her. Chris waits fo the answer. LINDA (CONT’D) I know you’1l take care of him. Then Chris watches Linda walk past him until she reaches partly opened door and goes out  57. Chris remains alone. After a while, he turns and looks at Christopher. The boy’s sleeping on the sofa under the message Chris covered up. Chris looks at his son. IT’S A MOMENT DURING WHICH CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: TAKES THE MEASURE OF THE RISKS THE PROGRAM RUNS FOR THEM
dialogues.text: AGAINST HOW HIS AND CHRISTOPHER’S LIVES CAN BE IMPROVED B IT. Chris watches his son sleep. Then Chris steps over to kitchen phone. In time there, he’s placed a call and keep his voice pretty low so he doesn’t wake his son.

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Hello. It’s Chris Gardner.

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hi, Chris.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I called to thank you again for inviting me in.

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE
dialogues.text: I responded to your determination, Chris.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I appreciate it. Jay?

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Time passes. CHRIS (CONT’D) I’d be real pleased to be in the program.

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE
dialogues.text: That’s good, Chris. CLOSE ON CHRIS on the phone; he’s expression shows some uncertainty over what their future holds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On another day, Chris and his acquaintance Wayne load Chr scanners from Chris’s old apartment into Wayne’s car.  58.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (urging Wayne to slow down) Careful.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Be careful. Chris loads one in. Then he and Wayne enter the car. Christopher’s in the back seat. The car pulls out, then h directly across the street to a motel lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christopher eats cereal at the small kitchen dining table They’re in a residence motel room now with fewer furnishi Chris enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (with a great deal of fatherly enthusiasm) Hey, it’s Saturday!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (same enthusiasm) Let’s go play some basketball!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Then go sell a bone density scanner! Chris leaves. Christopher remains at the table, puzzling the last part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris has taken Christopher to a park basketball court in middle of the city. Christopher takes a shot, misses and a scanner that rests near the court.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (quietly) Shit...  59. Chris gets the ball. CHRIS (CONT’D) Try not to hit that. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Okay. Chris dribbles the ball, smiling. CHRISTOPHER (CONT’D) I’m going pro.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (watching Christopher for a stretch) Yeah, I don’t know. Chris isn’t smiling now. CHRIS (CONT’D) (kindly) Come here. Listen. Christopher walks over. Chris looks at him. CHRIS (CONT’D) (kindly) ) You’11 probably be about as good as I was. That’s the way it works. And I was below average, so you’1l probably ultimately rank somewhere around there. Around average. Christopher listens; his eyes are a little wider now with new set of facts. CHRIS (CONT’D) You’11 excel at a number of things. Not this, though. So I don’t want you out here day and night, bouncing this ball. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Okay. A couple moments pass. CHRISTOPHER (CONT’D) Why did we move to a motel?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Because I’m getting a better job.  60. Christopher makes a curious expression; he’s a smart chil and doesn’t add that up. Chris looks down at him. CHRIS (CONT’D) You have to trust me.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: I trust you.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (looking at his watch) It’s time to go. They head off the court. Christopher’s trailing.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on. Keep up.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: When’s Mom coming back?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early Saturday, Chris and his son are the only ones in th train car. They ride through the city with the scanner between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris and his son walk through an Oakland business distri The streets are pretty quiet still; Chris carries his scanner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris has sold the scanner. He cashes a check at the coun while Christopher waits beside him. Christopher’s checkin out some Clark candy bars for sale on the counter. He doe say anything though. Chris sees him.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (to Christopher ) Do you want one? Christopher nods. Chris faces the clerk again and points the candy bars. CHRIS (CONT’D) One of these, please.  61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Chris wears a new suit and parts company with Christopher outside daycare right under the word Happynes

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I’1l see you after school.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: You’re going to get me?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m going to get you. Christopher heads inside. Chris stands under the word Happyness, looking at him go.

dialogues.speaker: LATER, (MORNING)
dialogues.text: Chris is dressed in the new suit; he rides the bus along bay as the sun rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Office Manager ALAN FRAKESH, 38, leads the entire group o twenty Dean Witter interns, including Chris, from the Dea Witter building toward some destination across the street each is clean-cut and fresh-looking. The group reaches a corner where three streets intersect. Frakesh gestures to number of skyscrapers visible around them.

dialogues.speaker: FRAKESH
dialogues.text: Mehvney Industrial and Sanco Oil have the twelve hundred building. Lee-Ray shipping is across the street. Chris listens; he’s glancing at the size of the skyscrape FRAKESH (CONT’D) In a couple weeks you’1ll get cold call sheets with the phone numbers of employees from the Fortunes 500s in the financial district. If you canvas the district you can pool from sixty Fortune companies. Coffees and working lunches can be fun occasions to familiarize possible clients with our packages. We need you to bring them in. Match their needs and goals to a package. And sign them up.  62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris and the other interns sit around a conference table Frakesh distributes pretty thick textbooks.

dialogues.speaker: FRAKESH
dialogues.text: The board examination isn't just a simple pass fail. It’s an evaluatory tool we use to separate applicants. Frakesh checks his watch. FRAKESH (CONT’D) Okay. Five minute break. Back at two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris is on break, waiting to cross the broad intersectio out front of the skyscraper. The FIRST PARTNER from Chris early interview has come out as well and stands beside Ch hailing a cab.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: Hi...

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Hi. The guy can’t recall Chris’s name. CHRIS (CONT’D) Chris.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: How are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I’m good. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: How’s first day?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Good. Exciting.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: (kidding, looking around and meaning why’s Chris outside) You’re not quitting are you?  63.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No. Five minute break. (nodding across the street) I’m grabbing a candy bar. We’re doing board prep.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: (like board prep’s hard) Man. I remember mine... While the first partner reminisces, Chris sees something. CHRIS’S POV The Filipino sits across the street on a bus bench; he’s Chris’s scanner on his lap. From across the street, Chris looks at him. FIRST PARTNER (CONT’D) : it was an hour exam. Not three like yours...

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: If I sold every scanner I had, I might still come up short by the end of the program.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: ...and we had no world markets on it...

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So I was watching a guy with my rent on his lap waiting for a bus to somewhere else. Chris is focused on the Filipino. He sees the bus coming him a block south.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: We didn’t cover taxes either. It was still a pain in the ass...

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I couldn’t run right off while he was talking, because I’d look like a freak. Chris sees the bus pulling up.  64.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But the bus was coming.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (to the first partner) Well, I’m down to two minutes. On my break.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: Yeah, Frakesh is a prick about it, too, I bet.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: It’s my first day, so...

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: Okay, get going. Chris begins to cross the street. He’s got to walk, altho the bus has arrived. After a moment, it clears; the bus b is empty. The guy has gotten on. Chris has to walk until he turns a corner where the bus h gone. He finally does; he’s out of sight of the first par and starts to run.

dialogues.speaker: SAME
dialogues.text: The Filipino sits near the window. He has the scanner. At that moment, Chris catches up to the bus and comes into v running up alongside the guy’s window. IT’S AT THIS POINT THAT CHRIS GETS HIT BY A CAR.

dialogues.speaker: FILIPINO GUY
dialogues.text: Whoa....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris lays on the pavement in the middle of the city stre His eyes are open, but he seems stunned. Cars come right him.

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH GUY
dialogues.text: Hey, asshole. A SPANISH GUY hauls Chris up to a knee then quickly over few feet to the sidewalk as a car swerves by. SPANISH GUY (CONT’D) Are you all right, man? Fuck.  65.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (standing now, coming around further) Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH GUY
dialogues.text: What are you doing? I could have killed you. The guy’s car is pulled over behind them; he’s the driver struck Chris. SPANISH GUY (CONT’D) Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH GUY
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I was trying to catch the bus.

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH GUY
dialogues.text: You’re all right?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. They stand around there for a while.

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH GUY
dialogues.text: Gross, man. Your thumb. Man, gross.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (not following the guy) What?

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH GUY
dialogues.text: You got a fucked up thumb. Chris’s thumb stiffly points opposite the way it ought to SPANISH GUY (CONT’D) Man, your thumb’s fucked up.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (noticing it) Yeah... After a moment, Chris starts to walk away.  66.

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH GUY
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH GUY
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Work.

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH GUY
dialogues.text: We should wait for the cops.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I’m on a five minute break. I have like a minute left.

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH GUY
dialogues.text: You got hit by a car. Go to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I can’t. I’m in a competitive internship at Dean Witter. Chris waves then begins to run back the way he came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris hustles back into the conference room. The other interns are all seated and working from their textbooks. Chris takes his seat; he picks up his pencil to write, ev though that thumb’s pointing in a different direction tha everyone else's.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This part of my life is called...

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (privately, flexing his hand) Ow... fuck...

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...intern. Show up early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early, The wide office space of open desks is empty excep for Chris and his twenty intern competitors, reading earl market charts on computers.  67.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Run with coffee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On another day, Chris is dressed for work and runs awkwar up a financial district sidewalk with a carry carton full coffees; he spills on his wrist

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Fuck...

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Favors for Frakesh. Our office manager. All day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris sits at the end of a cubicle row of interns making calls from a employee sheet marked Pacific Transportation He’s got Marshall Slauson: Billing circled in red.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (with a pretty fast rhythm) Our office is a block from Pacific. I’d be glad to come over and share our information with you. Even the eight hundred dollars from your profit sharing, if that’s all you moved into the market yearly-- (listening) Sure... (listening) You have my number. (listening) Call me with any questions, Mr. Slauson. Anytime. Alan Frakesh walks up to Chris’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Who wants to get me a doughnut? He’s looking at Chris. So Chris has to get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris runs up the same coffee-spilling sidewalk, holding doughnut.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Stay late.  68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris is on the cold call phone again. There’s all kind o cold call chatter from the interns around him.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Even the four hundred dollars from your pension can accrue to three times-- (listening) Accrue means adds up. Quickly. Into more money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At day’s end, the intersection before the skyscraper is mostly quiet; CHRIS, THOUGH, HAS LEFT THE SKYSCRAPER AND SPRINTS ACROSS IT.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Then catch an A train by six.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Chris rides the train.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Then the crosstown.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Chris rides east through San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: To the blue line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris is on another el. CHRIS (V.O. The twenty-two

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris rides another bus.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: To the place they can’t spell Happiness.  69. EXT. MRS. CHU’S DAYCARE - LATER Christopher waits outside the facility with Mrs. Chu unde their mural. He’s the last kid. Chris runs up for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris studies his textbook in their small kitchenette. Christopher’s down for the night on a cot in the living r beside him. Chris is writing. His thumb’s still hurting.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (from pain in his hand) Ah...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: (meaning what’s wrong) What?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: My thumb.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I got hit by a car.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: On Pacific?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Where on your body?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: The back of my legs. I don’t remember really.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: How’d you hurt your thumb then?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I landed on it. (kindly) Go to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Were you on the street?  70.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I was running on the street. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Don’t do that. You can get hurt.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (smiling) Okay... Go to sleep. Chris finishes a page of his textbook. Then he closes it. Then he opens his checkbook to pay bills he’s got there. looks at the amount he’s got: $138.00. Chris stares at th number for a while. He’s concerned of course.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Then eight hours later... reverse. *The film speeds up and takes Chris and Christopher on a quick-motion glimpse through their many transfers through city back to daycare and work

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris runs up to the skyscraper for work again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera tracks along the cubicle row where each intern sits making calls.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Whoever brought in the most money after five months was usually hired. They work frantically.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They were all working their way up call sheets to sign clients. An intern scratches a name he called from the bottom of a sheet titled State Farm. Chris sits in the last cubicle.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They’d stay till eight, but I had Chris. I didn’t have the same time to work my way up a Sheet. Chris looks at his sheet.  71. CHRIS’S POV The sheet is titled Bell Western. THE CAMERA PANS UP THE

dialogues.speaker: TOP
dialogues.text: Walter Ribbon: Pension Fund Manager. Chris looks at the name Ribbon and decides to dial it. He awaits an answer.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Walter Ribbon’s office.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Chris Gardner for Walter Ribbon.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Concerning?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I’m calling from Dean Witter.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Just a moment. Chris, surprised he’s getting through, waits by the phone

dialogues.speaker: WALTER RIBBON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Ribbon. This is Chris Gardner. I’m calling from Dean Witter.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER RIBBON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah, Chris.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Mr. Ribbon. I wondered if you’d give me a few moments to discuss our products and how I might--

dialogues.speaker: WALTER RIBBON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Can you be here in a half-hour?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yes.  72.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER RIBBON
dialogues.text: I just had someone cancel. Come now. I can give you a few minutes before the Giants game. Chris is already taking off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Office manager Alan Frakesh is on his way in with a cup o coffee. He encounters Chris as Chris hustles out.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Hey, Alan.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Hey, man. Do you have five minutes?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Man, I guess. I’m meeting Walter Ribbon at Bell Western at three.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Because I have no minutes. I’m supposed to present commodities to Bromer. Could you move my car? That would really help me out.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Lowery. (pointing) Half block. Lemon Tercel.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Where am I moving it?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (like it’s real easy) Other side of Lowery. They’re streetsweeping. There’s spaces.  73.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) All right... Alan has handed Chris keys.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Hold on to these. I have backups in my desk. Chris begins to go.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you have to jimmy that.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Jimmy what?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You have to jimmy the key. And the other doors don’t unlock. Alan makes a “jimmying” gesture to indicate what Chris ne to do.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have to jimmy it. Lemon Tercel. Privately, Chris is a little more pissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris has approached a parked lemon Tercel. He puts the k in the driver’s door. He begins to “jimmy” it. It doesn’t open. Chris messes around with it a little more. It still won’t open. He looks at his watch. INT. WALTER RIBBON’S OFFICE, BELL WESTERN BUILDING - SAME Fund manager WALTER RIBBON sits behind his desk, meeting a couple younger associates; THERE’S A PROMINENT OFFICE C behind him reading 2:42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back on Lowery, Chris continues to jimmy the key in the l

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (frustrated, to himself) I’m jimmying it. Come on. This is jimmying it.  74. INT. WALTER RIBBON’S OFFICE - SAME The associates have cleared out of Ribbon’s office. Walte does paper work at his desk. THE CLOCK BEHIND HIM READS 2 INT. ALAN’S TERCEL, MOVING - LATER Chris has finally gained entry and drives around north Sa Francisco, trying to find parking. INT. WALTER RIBBON’S OFFICE - LATER Walter Ribbon sits at his desk. The large wall clock that looms behind him reads 2:55. RIBBON WEARS A SAN FRANCISCO GIANTS BASEBALL CAP now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris has pulled the Tercel into a metered parking space. He’s left the driver’s side. But after he’s shut the door realizes he’s left his work materials inside. He puts the in. The door won’t unlock, so Chris begins to “jimmy” it again.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Shit... INT. WALTER RIBBON’S OFFICE - SAME The prominent clocks reads 3:01. Ribbon wears the ball ca but also takes a mitt from his drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris stands at the meter beside the parked Tercel. He’s his work case with him and has been looking through his pockets for change. He doesn’t have any quarters. Chris l at his watch. Then he looks back at the meter. Then he ju takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris runs with his workbag up the Sierra Boulevard sidew

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris stands on the sidewalk, looking around for an addre he can’t find. A BUSINESSMAN WALKS BY.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Where’s 223 east, man? It should be right here.  75.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: This is 200 west. You have to cross Cortez.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (quietly) Fuck...

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: You have to go east four blocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again, Chris is running through San Francisco. INT. LOBBY, WALTER RIBBON’S OFFICE BUILDING - LATER Chris has jogged into the skyscraper lobby. He caught an elevator just as the doors close; the elevator is ABSOLUT PACKED THOUGH, so much so that it’s absurd for Chris to t to enter, which out of desperation he does anyway. A maintenance worker up front pushes him out.

dialogues.speaker: MAINTENANCE WORKER
dialogues.text: Get the fuck out of here, man. Chris steps back and lets the elevator go up without him. hits the button. Soon, another elevator opens. Chris jump in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris is alone in the elevator going up; there’s easy listening coming through the elevator speaker that cuts across Chris’s frantic mood, so it’s a peculiar few momen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter Ribbon is no longer there. There is just an empty, high-backed chair behind his desk with the large clock reading 3:17 hanging on the wall behind it. INT. RECEPTION DESK, LOBBY, WALTER RIBBON’S OFFICE - LATE As the receptionist finishes a call, Chris approaches her arrives at the desk. They look at each other. Chris smile and tries to come across bright-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Hi, I’m Chris Gardner.  76. INT. ELEVATOR, WALTER RIBBON’S OFFICE BUILDING - LATER Chris stands among a crowd of office-workers in an elevat that’s going down. His expression is the opposite of the he was just making; it’s clear he didn’t see Walter Ribbo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dispirited, Chris returns to the parked Tercel and FINDS PARKING TICKET ON THE WINDSHIELD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, Chris rides the metro train. Pretty soon, he sees OFFICE MANAGER ALAN FRAKESH, having just boarded, walking down the aisle. They make eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Hey...

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Why are you on the train?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I’m just cruising up to Morgan Stanley. For a presentation. Parking in the financial district’s a pain in the ass.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Alan takes an empty space beside Chris.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Thanks for moving my car.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: That’s all right. It’s on Sierra.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (like Sierra’s pretty far) Sierra?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Chris reaches into his work bag.  77. CHRIS (CONT’D) There weren’t any spaces around Lowery. Where you said. Chris TAKES THE PARKING TICKET OUT. CHRIS (CONT’D) I missed an appointment at Bell Western. With Walter Ribbon. Walter Ribbon left.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Man...

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I was twenty-three minutes late. Now Chris is A LITTLE MORE THAN VAGUELY HOLDING THE TICKE

dialogues.speaker: OUT TOWARD ALAN TO ALLOW ALAN TO ASSUME IT AND THE
dialogues.text: RESPONSIBILITY OF PAYING FOR IT. Alan has seen the ticket isn’t taking it.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Tell him some Dean Witter business came up.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (pissed) Okay...

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Something for a current client. That’11 seem industrious.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah... Chris HAS CONTINUED TO HOLD THE PARKING TICKET OUT. FRAKE CONTINUES TO IGNORE IT. So Chris just reaches over and pu the ticket on Alan’s body. Alan, though, will not take possession of the parking ticket. He merely allows it to slide slowly down his sportcoat sleeve and come to rest o the train seat between him and Chris. HE DOESN’T EVEN ACKNOWLEDGE THAT THAT JUST HAPPENED either; he’s just kep looking straight ahead. Chris looks at Alan. Alan won’t make eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What follows is a series of dissolves featuring the train interior with Alan and Chris sitting with the ticket equa between them.  78. Through dissolves, the passage of time is indicated by th changing crowd of passengers around Chris and Alan Frakes New riders appear and disappear. Throughout the sequence, though, the ticket remains exactly between the two men. S the train comes to a stop. Alan rises.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Thanks again for moving my car. Alan walks down the aisle to leave the train. He leaves t ticket behind. Chris remains beside it. Alan has disembar The train begins moving again, taking Chris and his parki ticket somewhere else. Then Chris puts it in his workbag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris and Christopher sit across from one another at a bo Chris pays the parking ticket with his checkbook

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We should get home pretty soon.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (kindly) Finish up.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Okay. (looking at the checkbook) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Paying bills. A parking ticket.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: You don’t have a car anymore.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I know. Chris looks down at his checkbook. CHRIS’S POV The amount he’s just written as his balance is $64.08 Chris looks at that for a while. He’s worried.  79.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I need to take you with me to a couple doctors’ offices tomorrow. Okay? For a sales call.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Then... possibly... we’ll go toa baseball game. Possibly. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: (pleased) Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a jarring cut because for the first time, the settin not the city. Chris and Christopher ride in the bus toget THEY’RE WEARING BRAND NEW SAN FRANCISCO GIANTS BASEBALL C SO FRESH THEIR BRIMS AREN’T BENT. Chris has a scanner wit him. Out the window pass spread out suburban homes and tr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, Chris and Christopher, in their fresh caps, walk p suburban houses.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You don’t understand what?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Are we going to the game?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We’re possibly going to the game. Do you know what possibly means?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Like probably.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No... Possibly means we might, we might not. Probably means there’s a good chance we’re going.  80.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (testing him) What does probably mean?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: It means there’s a good chance.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What does possibly mean?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: I know what it means.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: It means we’re not going to the game. Chris laughs. He looks at his son for a while.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: How’d you get so smart?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Because you’re smart. Chris smiles. They fall silent and keep walking. After a while, Chris’s expression shifts to doubt and concern whe his son’s really right about that

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris has knocked on the door of a large private home. Christopher waits beside him. Soon, Walter Ribbon answers door.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Mr. Ribbon?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER RIBBON
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.text: Well, we’1l leave you alone. I’m sorry about yesterday. It just wasn’t enough time to finish my work and get across the district. I was eager, and probably too optimistic about getting over there.
