Then Chris holds him around the he bends him and takes him to the ground. They start fightin down there while the line scatters then starts cheering t on.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR
dialogues.text: Out of the line! THE PASTOR HAS COME OUT FROM THE SHELTER. He yanks Chris the larger man.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Both of you. Out of the line. They’re on their feet now, but neither of them moves.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get out!

dialogues.speaker: HOMELESS MAN
dialogues.text: He sliced in front of him. A guy farther back in line has spoken up. HOMELESS MAN (CONT’D) (to the pastor) He sliced in front of him in line.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR
dialogues.text: Who did? The homeless guy doesn’t want to say it out loud. He nods the larger man.  102.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (to the Pastor) I got here first. Chris is catching his breath. CHRIS (CONT’D) I was here first. The Pastor looks at Chris. Then he looks at Christopher. Chris looks at the Pastor with the clearest communication desperation he’s shown yet CHRIS (CONT’D) I came from my job. We got here. We got in line. This guy just came up. He shoved in front. I went and got my son and we got here. We were here on time. Someone told me we had to be here on time. We were on time. The Pastor stares at him for a while.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR
dialogues.text: All right. (to the large man) Get out of line, Rodney. The large man shuffles off. Chris takes his place in the again. Chris tries to calm himself. Christopher’s holding onto his arm now because he’s freaked out. Then Chris not his dress shirt’s ripped.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (quietly) Fuck...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is small and real basic. There’s a wood desk and bed. It’s dark. Chris lights a candle.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Why don’t we have lights?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: It’s two dollars for electricity. We need breakfast tomorrow. Come on. Let’s get washed. They’ve come into the small bathroom. Christopher’s taken his shirt. Chris runs water from the sink over a cloth.  103. CHRIS (CONT’D) Can you stand up here?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Yeah... Chris picks his son up. He stands him on the low counter beside the sink. He begins to wash him with the cloth. Ti passes.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What’s your favorite color? I was wondering about that.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Green.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What do you like that’s green?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Trees.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Holly.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: The Christmas stuff?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: That’s good. Chris washes Christopher with the rag; he’s feeling some in that hand. CHRIS (CONT’D) (to himself, quietly) Damn, man...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (quietly) I think I broke my other thumb.  104. Chris doesn’t say anything else. He keeps washing Christo up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christopher lays in the bed. Chris sits on the edge, putt him to bed.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I have to go sit in the hall and fix this, okay? Chris has nodded at the busted scanner that rests nearby. CHRIS (CONT’D) I’1l be right out there. I’1l leave the door open a little.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Okay. Chris rises. He heads for the lighted common hallway. He turns back because he wants to reassure Christopher.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I’m just going to be right out here.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Okay. I trust you. Chris looks at his son; he smiles, waves, then takes the scanner out to the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris sits on the hallway floor near the open door of his room. He’s using the hallway light to help him repair his scanner. He’s becoming frustrated by a part that won’t function as a BOARDER IN AN OLD ARMY JACKET walks by.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (to the scanner) You fucking piece of shit.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: What did you call me?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Not you. This. Chris has his hands on the scanner. The guy looks at Chri for a while. Then he walks off.  105. Chris tries to rig the thing another way. It fails as wel Then he gets up. He goes into his room. He’s gone for a moment, then he comes out to the hallway again with one o his financial textbooks. He’s taken a seat beside the scanner. He starts to do his work out there. Then the lig go dead. MAN’S VOICE (0.S.) Lights out. INT. CHRIS’S SHELTER ROOM - LATER It’s pretty dark in their room. Chris sits near the windo trying to read his book by the streetlight coming in. He stops. He stares at the room. Before long, he starts to b up. He seems to be losing it like he lost it in the apart painting scene, but this time he can’t make any noise. Hi feelings this time just take the form of silent, anguishe crying. Then Christopher, who’s apparently awake in bed across the room, asks him something.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: How are you going to tie your tie?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (didn’t catch all of it) What?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: How are you going to tie your tie? With your hands hurt?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I’1l get it done.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I’1l get it done. Go to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: No way. That’s why animals can’t make tools. Because of no thumbs.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Go to sleep. The sooner you get to sleep, the shorter the night’1l be. Christopher doesn’t say anything else. Chris leans agains the wall by the window. He’s exhausted. After a while, he looks back at his book  106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the morning, Chris sits on the bed, nearly dressed for work. Christopher’s with him, helping him get his tie tie properly.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Is it through the middle?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the register, Chris is showing the clerk a mini light and transmitter.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: One of these.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Six weeks.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (upset about that delay) For a K transmitter? And a bulb? Christopher’s looking at a video game shelf. CLERK (CONT’D) Yeah. Those are English. Six weeks.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (upset at the delay) Do you have a Thompson wire?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: That won’t work.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah, it will. We used them in the Navy to send the same electrical weight. Let me try it. The guy enters the number. CLERK (CONT’D) Three weeks. Chris takes the news in.  107.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris walks with Christopher. He’s dressed for work, but carrying his suitcase; Christopher has a bookbag.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You weren’t able to leave your belongings behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris approaches the lobby of Dean Witter for work; he’s still got his luggage. He encounters another young Bell Western executive PAUL going in.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Hi, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (greeting him) What’s happening, Chris? Paul takes notice of the stuff Chris holds.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (meaning what’s he got that stuff for) What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Work trip. They enter the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris and Paul sit together at the conference table.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Your wife works at Bell Western, too, right?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Well, then you should use the pension. Because you’re paying taxes twice.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: For real?  108.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah... because you’re using your taxable income...

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I was able to finish this stuff pretty quickly. Chris has placed income amounts in different sections on paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The math. I had to finish quickly. To get to the Altmont rooms by five. Chris looks up at a wall clock that reads 4:30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris sprints away from the skyscraper.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Chris rides the train.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Chris rides the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris is on another el, tapping the window glass from adrenaline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris and Christopher hustle with their things up San Francisco’s King Street, toward a bus stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit on a sidewalk bench waiting for the bus. There’s wide public clock behind them. It reads 4:50. Chris taps foot like he’s frantic. There’re others waiting. The bus comes. Chris rises quickly.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Let’s go. Christopher’s preoccupied by a kid’s book he’s reading.  109. CHRIS (CONT’D) Let’s go!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: I want to read this.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: On the bus.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Just this part.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Goddamnit. Get up! Come on! It’s hurting Chris to talk to his son this way. When Christopher catches up to him, they find the bus so full there’s not room for all the commuters waiting on the sidewalk. Chris is shoulder to shoulder with an older lad He jockeys his arm past her to get a front position. A yo guy in a suit’s watching.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Why don’t you let the lady on? Chris doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Man, that’s not cool. Chris tries to ignore the guy.

dialogues.speaker: GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s not cool. Let the--

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Why don’t you get the fuck away from me! The guy’s been startled. CHRIS (CONT’D) Get the fuck away from me. Right now. Chris gets Christopher up into the bus; he follows him on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside of the Almont church shelter building, Chris and Christopher, in the front of the line, get accepted insid for an open room.  110.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s evening now. Chris and his son sit under a streetlig on the stoop of the shelter building. Chris reads his textbook. Up the street, prostitutes stand on the corner. Chris looks at Christopher for a while. The boy seems rea calm and more or less contented. Chris keeps looking at h

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You’re a good boy. Christopher looks over at him. CHRIS (CONT’D) You’re a wonder. You know? Christopher smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Can I look at that fire truck?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Christopher heads off down the sidewalk where some fireme repair a hydrant. Their truck’s parked there. CHRIS (CONT’D) Just don’t bother them. Chris watches him go. Then Chris looks back at his book f while.

dialogues.speaker: PROSTITUTE
dialogues.text: Get your kid some dinner. Chris turns and sees a PROSTITUTE has come up to him. She holding out a five dollar bill.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (declining) That’s okay. They have dinner here.

dialogues.speaker: PROSTITUTE
dialogues.text: Get him dessert.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: That’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: PROSTITUTE
dialogues.text: Do you think this is dirty money?  111.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (smiling) I don’t think there’s any such thing. I just don’t want him to see me taking money. He thinks I know what I’m doing. She puts the bill away. Chris checks on Christopher. Christopher looks over at them from down the sidewalk. He makes eye contact with his dad. Then he waves hello with good nature like he was waving from a carousel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is full of cafeteria tables. Forty or so men eat scattered positions around the room. Chris sits at a tabl with his son. They don’t talk for a while.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Who called you Ten Gallon Head?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: You said they called you that. who called you that?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: My aunts. Some teachers.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Because you like to read?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. And do puzzles. Math.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: What did you read?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I read about people’s lives. Biographies. You know what those are?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Books about people’s lives? Chris nods.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I liked to read about interesting lives. Cool lives.  112.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Like whose lives?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Miles Davis. I don’t know. Thomas Jefferson. Christopher Columbus.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Who’s Thomas Jefferson?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: President. Architect. Musician. He wrote the Declaration of Independence.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: What’s that about?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: It’s about... I don’t know. It’s about people trying to be free, so they can try to be happy.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: What instrument did he play?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: The violin. I think. Or the cello or something. I don’t really remember. Chris looks at Christopher as he returns to his meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The twenty interns sit around the table in the largest Wi conference room. They’re taking a timed exam. A proctor s up front. Soon, a MALE INTERN stands up and heads for the proctor to turn in his test. Some others look up - they’r struggling and are pissed the assured male intern has finished already. But as this male intern walks to the do Chris stands up; he’s finished as well. The male intern l at Chris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two ride the elevator down together. Some time passes THE FIRST PARTNER FROM CHRIS’S FIRST INTERVIEW RIDES BEHI THEM.  113.

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: (to Chris) Did you finish the whole thing, or did you have to go somewhere, or..?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I have to go somewhere. The guy nods. He seems relieved to resume believing he finished earlier than the others. CHRIS (CONT’D) But I finished the whole thing, too.

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: (a little bummed) Oh. Good.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. You?

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What did you think of the graphs?

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: Easy. Chris nods.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What about the essay question? There is a long pause.

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: Essay question?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: On the back. Yeah. Some more time passes.

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: Shit. The guy hits the button for the next floor. When the door open, he gets off quickly. Chris remains behind; he’s laughing.  114. But he’s also conveying the same vibe the guy was just gi off - satisfaction he found the test easier than his colleagues. He makes eye contact with the first partner; partner’s looking back like he found the episode telling funny as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris and the First Partner are outside at the curb, Chri waiting to cross, the partner hailing a cab. A BUSINESSMA passing sees Chris.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: Chris. Chris faces the guy.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (recognizing him) Jeff, right? The Giants game?

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. You were going to call.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I never got your number.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: Okay, man. Here. The guy takes a business card out BUSINESSMAN (CONT’D) Call me. While the two have been talking the First Partner’s been searching his pockets for something. Chris has his wallet to put the guy’s card away.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: Fuck. Chris, hey, do you have five bucks? Chris stands there for a moment FIRST PARTNER (CONT’D) My wallet’s upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (trying to keep his money) Do you want me to get it?  115.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: No, I have to get to Cal Bank. At five.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah... um...

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: (kidding) I’m good for it.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (smiling along) I know... Chris takes a five dollar bill from his wallet, leaving a couple dollars left. He hands it to the First Partner. Th the First Partner takes off for his cab. Chris stands the watching him go off with money Chris needed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christopher and Chris have been admitted into the shelter foyer, into a shorter line to sign in and pay. They’re on guy back from paying. A CHURCH-WORKER CLERK’s explaining billing to the guy; Chris stands behind him listening.

dialogues.speaker: CHURCH WORKER
dialogues.text: Two dollars to stay. Two to eat. Two covers electricity. Chris is holding the two dollars he’s left with. He waits there for a while, then he looks at Christopher.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Are you hungry? Christopher nods. CHRIS (CONT’D) Did you eat at school?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: The second session?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: (not following him) What?  116.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: In the afternoon? Christopher shakes his head. Chris looks at him. Time goe by. CHRIS (CONT’D) Okay. Come on. Chris leads Christopher out of the line. They head out th shelter doorway for the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, at night, Chris and Christopher sit at the window counter. Christopher’s eating a piece of pizza. Chris studies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Christopher waits, Chris pays the city station attendant with the dollar.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Later at night, Chris and his son are among a few other f on the train. Christopher’s coloring. Chris studies his books.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Later, Chris and his son are the only ones in the car. It moving back the other direction. Christopher’s sleeping. Chris is awake. He’s looking out the window again, much l he was in the picture’s early scenes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next day, Chris leaves a strip mall shop door over wh a banner reads Blood Center of the Pacific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris meets with two professional women at a cafe table o the sidewalk. Christopher sits at the next table, colorin

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (to one of the women) How long have you been at Bell Western?

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PROFESSIONAL WOMEN
dialogues.text: Eight years.  117.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Good. Then you can start splitting into an IRA for stocks.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PROFESSIONAL WOMEN
dialogues.text: I can do that already?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You could have done it last year.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PROFESSIONAL WOMEN
dialogues.text: Great... The second woman folds her paperwork up.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND PROFESSIONAL WOMAN
dialogues.text: Are we all set?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PROFESSIONAL WOMEN
dialogues.text: Thanks, Chris.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Thank you, Ann. They’ve all stood to leave one another.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND PROFESSIONAL WOMAN
dialogues.text: Have fun on your trip. Chris has picked up his suitcase he’s had with him. He wa goodbye to the departing pair of women. Christopher’s wit him now.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: What trip? Chris stands around there with his suitcase for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Our trip uptown to Radio Shack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk faces the camera, holding a small electrical pa and bulb out to it.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Here’s your Thompson wire. Chris is facing the guy. He takes it.  118.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Chris and Christopher ride in the train together, among a of other working people going home. Chris holds the piece from Radio Shack.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: To repair the light.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Can I see it?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Chris hands the bulb to Christopher.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (calmly, smiling) Don’t drop it. Christopher takes the piece. CHRIS (CONT’D) Unless you want to keep living in the same room with me.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: I don’t mind. Chris smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You will. Christopher examines the electrical bulb. Chris looks ove him. Then Christopher looks at him again.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Why am I going to want my own room?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: You said I was going to want my own room.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah.  119.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Space. For privacy. Peace. Some time goes by.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Where are you going to be? Chris looks over at Christopher and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Next door.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: What am I going to do in there?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Whatever you want. Whatever makes you happy. Nap. Read. Dream. Christopher looks back at the bulb. Chris keeps looking a him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They’ve walked to the shelter district

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christopher’s in the one bed. Chris sits on the edge, say goodnight; it’s dark.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I’1l see you in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You’re warm enough?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Yeah... Chris tucks him in. CHRISTOPHER (CONT’D) You’re a good papa.  120. After a while of looking at his son, Chris smiles. Then C finishes squaring Christopher away. Then Chris takes the object he bought at Radio Shack and walks toward the scan left against the wall. INT. CHRIS’S SHELTER ROOM - LATER (NIGHT) In their dark room, as Christopher sleeps, Chris sits by window, trying to fix the scanner by the light from the window. It’s really dark. We can hear Chris clicking thin into place. He’s done. He looks at the machine. He gets r to press the button to test it. A long time goes by.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This part of my life... This part is called... Chris pushes the button. The machine makes an activation sound, then his room get lighted all the way up by the br blue light the scanner emits.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris sits on the perimeter wall of a fountain in the pub square. He’s dressed for his Dean Witter work. The Bell Western building is beside the square. Chris holds an informal meeting with A YOUNG BELL EXECUTIVE AND A COUPLE HIS COLLEAGUES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris leaves Dean Witter later. He’s carrying his scanner INT. DOCTOR’S OFFICE, MEETING ROOM - LATER Chris sits across from a DOCTOR. The scanner rests on the table between them.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Plug it in.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Four hundred and eighteen dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris and Christopher wait in line for the cash.  121.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: That was going to get me through the program. All the way to the end, and then some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, Chris and Christopher sit on a bus bench in a San Francisco neighborhood; they have their belongings with t Chris is feeling a measure of relief he hasn’t shown befo

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Are we going to the church place?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Where are we going? Chris thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Let’s go to a hotel.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Can we go back to the cave? Chris sits there.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Ever?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Because some things are fun the first time you do them. Then not so much the next time.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Like the bus?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah...  122. 4 hey sit there for a while. The bus comes.

dialogues.speaker: LATER, (EVENING)
dialogues.text: t’s become dark. The bus is crowded, so Chris and his son re seated close together near a lot of others standing in he aisle; Chris is looking out the window at the city goi Ys

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TaOH hris and Christopher have gone up a step to the lobby ntrance of the Holiday Inn San Francisco. oa

dialogues.speaker: NT. HOTEL ROOM, SAN FRANCISCO
dialogues.text: The room’s an average hotel room. A sofa’s right in the middle. The bed’s empty in the background. Chris and Christopher are asleep together on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next day, Chris and Christopher sit all alone togethe a really wide stretch of grass in Golden Gate Park

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: (in the middle of a conversation) Can people climb Mount Everest?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. People have.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: How high is it?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: A few miles. Four miles maybe.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The next day, I took work off, and we just went and sat in a field.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Where is Mt. Everest?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What country?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Yeah.  123.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Napal.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Far away from anything. Trumpet kids. Guitars on fire. Ben Cartwright. And my own constant, ten-year-long disappointment in my Ten Gallon Head... in my self.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris sits in his now familiar spot on the fountain wall front of the Bell Western building. He’s finishing signin some paper work with another young executive.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Thanks, Dean.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER YOUNG EXECUTIVE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Chris.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You’11 get these back in a week. Then you’1l start getting statements a couple weeks after that.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER YOUNG EXECUTIVE
dialogues.text: Okay. Thanks, Chris. Take care.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Take care. The guy heads off back to Bell western.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Because when I was young, and I’d get an A on a history test or whatever, I’d get this good feeling about all these things I could be. And then I was never any of them. Chris finishes up his part of the contracts.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I was gambling, during all this, that I could get back on my way to being one, which I guessed would feel like happiness. Before long, Jay Twistle walks up.  124.

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Hi, Jay.

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE
dialogues.text: Rumor has it you’ve signed thirty- one accounts from Bell western.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah... Jay smiles. CHRIS (CONT’D) I met some guys at a ball game. I got some cards. I worked them.

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE
dialogues.text: (impressed) I guess. They sit quietly for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, there’s a week left before we hire from the intern group. Are you getting nervous?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (smiling) I’m okay.

dialogues.speaker: TWISTLE
dialogues.text: Okay... They become quiet again. Then Twistle offers Chris his ha Then Jay Twistle gets up and goes. Chris sits on the foun wall by himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same group of partners that accepted Chris to the int program sits around their conference table. After a while Chris comes in.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: Hi, Chris.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Hi, Mr. Keane.  125. Chris nods hello to the others.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: Nice shirt.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (smiling) Thanks...

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: Sit down, please. Chris sits at the end of the table.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (smiling) I thought I’d wear a shirt because it’s the last day.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: That’s good. Thanks. We appreciate that. Some time passes. FIRST PARTNER (CONT’D) Wear one tomorrow, though. Okay? Chris looks across the table at the first partner. FIRST PARTNER (CONT’D) Because tomorrow’s going to be your first day. If you’d like to work here as a broker. Chris doesn’t say anything. FIRST PARTNER (CONT’D) Would you like to work here? Chris doesn’t speak right off. He’s getting himself toget

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PARTNER
dialogues.text: Great. We couldn’t have been more pleased. Welcome, Chris. The others have stood up to congratulate and shake hands Chris. He’s risen as well.  126. FIRST PARTNER (CONT’D) Was it as easy as it looked? Chris takes a little while to answer.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (smiling) No... Chris keeps shaking hands around the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris rides down in an elevator crowded full of professio men and women. Chris is in the way back, out of view of t others because he’s crying. EXT. MRS. CHU’S DAYCARE - LATER Outside the building, Chris stands directly beneath the w Happyness, waiting for his son. Chris looks real tired li one might at the end of an ordeal, but he looks peaceful, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They’re waiting for the bus together. Christopher’s color Chris is just sitting there. The bus comes. It blocks the from view. After a while, it leaves. The two are still sitting there.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: The bus came.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (looking over at it) Oh...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Didn’t you see it?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No... I was thinking of stuff.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: (meaning what was he thinking of) What?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Just stuff. Grown up things. Don’t worry about it.  127. Christopher looks down the block at the bus.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Do you want to run up and get it?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No... I don’t want to run anywhere for a while. He takes Christopher’s hand. He smiles at his son. CHRIS (CONT’D) (kidding) Are you in a hurry to get somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: No, I don’t want to run either.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Okay. Let’s just sit here.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Okay. They remain there for a while, holding hands. A period of time goes by while they sit together. Then a scroll begin play over the image; it reads: Chris Gardner remained in San Francisco with his son. He Dean Witter after six years to found the investment firm Gardner Rich. Their assets in 2005 were 184 million dolla After Christopher’s graduation from college, Chris moved business to Chicago where he and Christopher live today. CREDITS BEGIN.
